  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
New data the FBI released today shows violent crime
  is on the rise in the United
    States and in 2006 particularly spiked in
  the country’s mid-size and large cities. Homicides climbed 6.7 percent
  in big cities and robberies increased more than any other crime. Bob Orr will
  have more of the figures tonight and Hari Sreenivasan will take a closer look
  at New Orleans’
  staggering rise in violent crime – especially since Hurricane Katrina.
 
And as more information comes out about the plot to
  bomb the jet fuel pipeline that supplies JFK
Airport in New York, our investigative correspondent
  Armen Keteyian will have the story of how safe our country’s fuel
  supplies are.
 
A militant Web site released video clips allegedly
  showing the ambush that captured three U.S.
  soldiers last month in Iraq.
  The group claims all three soldiers have been killed, but the U.S.
  military maintains that its search will go on. Lara Logan, who has spent the
  day with the U.S. commander
  for Iraq,
  Gen. David Petraeus, will have the story.
 
The United
    States could be facing a new threat from
  an old foe. Russian President Vladimir Putin warned that his country could
  take “retaliatory steps” if Washington
  continues plans to build a missile defense system in Europe.
  The threat came as President Bush headed to Europe
  for the G8 talks, Jim Axelrod will report.
 
And at The
    Hague, American-educated African warlord Charles
  Taylor failed to show up for the first day of his war-crimes trial. Sheila
  MacVicar will report on the trial, revisiting the crimes for which Taylor is being tried – including using child
  soldiers in the battlefields of diamond-rich Sierra Leone.
 
Finally, of the 1,800 athletes who competed in the
  Escape from Alcatraz triathlon this past
  weekend, one relay team stood out. It was composed of three Iraq veterans, each of whom had
  lost limbs in battle. Our John Blackstone will report on their story.
 
I hope you’ll join us,
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
